key_findings: Character-level log parsing using binary-coded decimal recognition achieves comparable accuracy to LLM-based parsers while requiring significantly fewer computational resources, making it suitable for resource-constrained environments.

Novel neural architecture aggregates character embeddings to estimate sequences of binary-coded decimals, enabling highly granular log template extraction that captures fine-grained details missed by existing parsers.

The proposed approach outperforms semantic parsers in efficiency while maintaining high accuracy on both revised Loghub-2k benchmark and manually annotated industrial datasets, demonstrating practical viability.

Low-resource requirements make the parser deployable in production environments where computational efficiency is critical, addressing the scalability challenges of processing large-scale system logs.

Character-level processing enables better handling of variable components and static templates in log messages, improving downstream tasks like anomaly detection, security enhancement, and audit trail analysis.
limitations: Limited evaluation on only two datasets may not fully demonstrate generalizability across diverse log formats and systems
Character-level processing may be slower than word-level approaches for very long log messages despite overall efficiency gains
problem_addressed: Inefficient and inaccurate log parsing that fails to capture fine-grained template details, leading to suboptimal performance in downstream tasks requiring precise pattern identification
prerequisites: Access to log data for training
